article.paragraph: Afonso IVEnglish:AlphonzoorAlphonse, orAffonso(Archaic Portuguese),AlfonsoorAlphonso(Portuguese-Galician languagesPortuguese-Galician) orAlphonsus(Latin).(IPA-ptɐˈfõsu; 8 February 1291 28 May 1357), calledthe Brave(lang-pto Bravono), wasKing of Portugal and the Algarvesfrom 1325 until his death. He was the only legitimate son of KingDenis of Portugalby his wifeElizabeth of Aragon.
article.heading: Early life
article.paragraph: Afonso, born inLisbon, was the rightful heir to the Portuguese throne. However, he was not Denis' favourite son, the old king preferring his illegitimate son, Afonso Sanches.cite bookJosé Miguel Pero-SanzSanta Isabel: Reina de Portugalhttps://books.google.com/books?id19 September 2011Palabra978-84-9840-546-069The notorious rivalry between the half brothers led to civil war several times. On 7 January 1325, Afonso's father died and he became king, whereupon he exiled his rival toCrown of CastileCastile, and stripped him of all the lands andfiefdomgiven by their father. From Castile, Afonso orchestrated a series of attempts to usurp the crown. After a few failed attempts at invasion, the brothers signed a peace treaty, arranged by Afonso's mother QueenElizabeth of AragonElizabeth.''Spain and Portugal'', Graeme Mercer Adam ed., J. D. Morris, 1906

In 1309, Afonso IV married InfantaBeatrice of Castile (12931359)Beatrice of Castile, daughter of KingSancho IV of Castileby his wifeMara de Molina. The first-born of this union was InfantaMaria of Portugal, Queen of CastileMaria of Portugal.
article.heading: King of Portugal and Algarve
article.paragraph: In 1325Alfonso XI of Castileentered a child-marriage withConstance of PeafielCostanza Manuelof Castile, the daughter of one of his regents. Two years later, he had the marriage annulled so he could marry Afonso's daughter, Maria of Portugal. Maria became Queen of Castile in 1328 upon her marriage to Alfonso XI, who soon became involved publicly with a mistress.Constance was imprisoned in a castle in Toro while her father,Juan Manuel, Prince of Villena, waged war against Alfonso XI until 1329. Eventually, the two reached a peaceful accord after mediation by Juan del Campo, Bishop of Oviedo; this secured Constance's release from prison.

The public humiliation of his daughter led Afonso IV to have his son and heir,Peter I of PortugalPeter, marry the no less aggrieved Castilian infanta, Constanza. Afonso subsequently started a war against Castile,peace arriving four years later, through the intervention of the Infanta Maria herself. A year after the peace treaty was signed inSeville, Portuguese troops played an important role in defeating theMoorsat theBattle of Ro Saladoin October 1340.
article.heading: Later life
article.paragraph: Image:Ins de Castro se jetant avec ses enfants aux pieds d'Alphonse IV roi.jpgleft300pxthumbIns on her knees in front of King AfonsoPolitical intrigue marked the last part of Afonso IV's reign, although Castille was torn by civil war after Alfonso XI died.Henry of Trastmarachallenged the new KingPedro of Castile, who sent many Castiliannobilitynoblesinto exile in Portugal. Afonso's heir,Peter I of PortugalPedro, fell in love with his new wife's lady-in-waiting,Ins de Castro. Ins was the daughter of an important noble family fromKingdom of GaliciaGalicia, with links (albeit illegitimate) to both the royal houses of Castile and Portugal. Her brothers were aligned with the Trastamara faction, and became favorites of crown prince Pedro, much to the dismay of others at the Portuguese court, who considered them Castilian upstarts. WhenConstance of Peafieldied weeks after giving birth to their third child, Pedro began living openly with Ins, recognized all her children as his and repudiated the idea of marrying anyone other than Ins herself. His father refused to go to war again against Castile, hoping his heir's infatuation would end, and tried to arrange another dynastic marriage for Pedro.

The situation became worse as the years passed and the aging Afonso lost control over his court. His grandson and Pedro's only legitimate son, future kingFerdinand I of PortugalFernando of Portugal, was a sickly child, while Ins' illegitimate children thrived. Worried about his legitimate grandson's life, and the growing power of Castile within Portugal's borders, Afonso ordered Ins de Castro first imprisoned in his mother's old convent inCoimbra, and then murdered in 1355. He expected his son to give in and marry a princess, but the heir became enraged upon learning of his lover's decapitation in front of their young child. Pedro put himself at the head of an army and devastated the country between theDouroand theMinho RiverMinhorivers before he was reconciled to his father in early 1357. Afonso died almost immediately after, in Lisbon in May.

Afonso IV's nicknamethe Bravealludes to his martial exploits. However, his most important accomplishments were the relative peace enjoyed by the country during his long reign and the support he gave to thePortuguese Navy. Afonso granted public funding to raise a proper commercial fleet and ordered the first Portuguese maritime explorations. The conflict with Pedro, and the explorations he initiated, eventually became the foundation of the Portuguese national epic,Os LusadasbyLus de Cames.

The dramatic circumstances of the relationship between father and son and Ins de Castro was used as the basis for the plot of more than twenty operas and ballets, as well as the "Nise lastimosa" and "Nise laureada" (1577) byJernimo Bermdez, 'Reinar despues de morir' byLus Vlez de Guevara, "Inez de Castro" byMary Russell Mitford, and La Reine morte (The Dead Queen) byHenry de Montherlant. The story with its tragic denouement is immortalized in several plays and poems in Portuguese, such asOs LusadasThe LusadasbyLus de Cames(canto iii, stanzas 118-135), and in Spanish, includingNise lastimosaandNise laureada(1577) byJernimo Bermdez,Reinar despues de morirbyLus Vlez de Guevara, as well as a play by French playwrightHenry de MontherlantcalledLa Reine morte(The Dead Queen).Mary Russell Mitfordalso wrote a drama based on the story entitledInez de Castro.Ins de Castrois a novel byMaria Pilar Queralt del Hierroin Spanish and Portuguese.
